abstract.p: Letter from Susan Subak (Natural Resources Defense Council) on Gregg Easterbrook's June 14 article defends assumptions underlying federal government's new assessment of global warming

block.p: Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, June 14) agrees that the scientific case for global warming is persuasive, but asserts that the federal government's new climate change assessment is based on assumptions ''far more pessimistic than those in mainstream climatology.''

Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, June 14) agrees that the scientific case for global warming is persuasive, but asserts that the federal government's new climate change assessment is based on assumptions ''far more pessimistic than those in mainstream climatology.''

In fact, the two climate-change scenarios used in the assessment are derived from models selected by the United Nations-affiliated Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Reflecting British and Canadian model results, the new assessment assumes there will be an average temperature increase over the United States of 5 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit.

The assessment confirms that global warming threatens our national treasures, from the coral reefs of Florida to the rain forests of Alaska. The alarming implications for the future of American society and environment show that the development of regional climate studies, like this one, is long overdue.
SUSAN SUBAK Senior Research Associate Natural Resources Defense Council Washington, June 15, 2000
